summary: SVG Filters - Clickjacking 2.0 (32 minute read) Clickjacking is a classic attack that involves covering up an iframe of some other website in an attempt to trick the user into unintentionally interacting with it. This article takes a look at the technique and its various applications.

title: Becoming great at listening
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-05, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fshreyasdoshi.substack.com%2Fp%2Fbecoming-great-at-listening%3Futm_source=tldrfounders/1/0100019aeea001ce-6f02cf55-211a-4c98-87e8-d5943a045391-000000/4hH7wQ7Ub7laSeFlpuVXT5xiSxsolPFqWkAJWh_t3ck=434
summary: Becoming great at listening (3 minute read) Your job as a listener is to consume decades of someone else's experience in minutes. This is impossible if you are busy mentally scripting your reply. The secret to world-class communication is to treat listening and thinking as mutually exclusive states. Turn off your analysis engine completely while they speak. When they finish, ask for a "thinking pause." That awkward silence is the only way to truly synthesize reality before you act on it.

summary: Tether in 2025: A Capital Analysis (15 minute read) Tether is like an unregulated bank rather than a simple money transmitter. Depending mostly on how harshly you treat BTC, Tether's total capital ratio ranges from ~10.9% (OK vs minimal regulatory standards) down to ~3.9% (bad vs market norms). Group-level profits and equity look big, but most sit outside the actual reserve entity and aren't legally committed to back USDT redemptions, so they can't be counted as true regulatory capital.

title: PeerDAS: How Fusaka Makes L2s Cheaper
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-05, Reading time: 2 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fthreadreaderapp.com%2Fthread%2F1986678949280391640.html%3Futm_source=tldrcrypto/1/0100019aeea04b68-add5b1a4-193c-4c74-801f-bbb2b7fbdaa3-000000/KvpEMhB7qjP1lc2cRHYtMQwKDOD32XG2tMh0TWuV820=434
summary: PeerDAS: How Fusaka Makes L2s Cheaper (2 minute read) Fusaka's main feature, PeerDAS, changes how Ethereum stores blob data. Instead of every node keeping full copies of each blob, nodes only store a small slice of every blob while still being able to verify that the full data exists. That means the network can safely handle many more blobs per block, which lowers data-availability costs for rollups. More blobs per block means cheaper L2 data and cheaper L2 transactions for users.

title: A Modern Guide to SQL JOINs
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-08, Reading time: 18 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fkb.databasedesignbook.com%2Fposts%2Fsql-joins%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdata/1/0100019afda5395a-c3bdafbc-7a92-4ae7-b877-cf8766adf713-000000/Vq-HqeMU6aczKZ8bWo1DOr4Fu7I01S3E3etCMv_-Byo=434
summary: A Modern Guide to SQL JOINs (18 minute read) LEFT JOIN with ID-only ON clauses forms the core foundation for SQL JOINs, preserving left-table rows and cleanly handling N:1 and 1:N relationships (with NULLs where needed). INNER JOIN is a filtered Cartesian product. Best practices include explicit aliases, N:1 join order for performance, nested-loop thinking, moving non-ID filters to WHERE, and avoiding Venn diagrams and non-equality ON conditions.

title: Cloudflare outage on December 5, 2025
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-08, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblog.cloudflare.com%2F5-december-2025-outage%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdevops/1/0100019afdeb0004-29db0d24-6ef5-486b-9d27-5dc19ce0de40-000000/rvmFs4rufKY66f-B88onk-wGhZylnaXRt4faPp-OxCU=434
summary: Cloudflare outage on December 5, 2025 (6 minute read) Cloudflare experienced a 25-minute network outage on December 5 that impacted approximately 28% of its HTTP traffic. This marks the company's second major incident in weeks.

People advocate for you in rooms you're not in.

title: How Exchanges Turn Order Books into Distributed Logs
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-09, Reading time: 21 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fquant.engineering%2Fexchange-order-book-distributed-logs.html%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b0303d3e5-f633ea4b-5ad9-4108-a61f-87f3396e029d-000000/9q9KHTxVfLB8Npi6AvYSKmGGgT6vCmA2rpLJeK2MsCU=434
summary: How Exchanges Turn Order Books into Distributed Logs (21 minute read) Order books are distributed logs of market events. This architecture guarantees fairness through deterministic ordering. Modern exchanges behave like ultra-low-latency log processors. The sequencer defines the timeline, the matching engine reduces that timeline into a book, and replication keeps the log durable without slowing the fast path.

title: The highest quality codebase
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-09, Reading time: 9 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fgricha.dev%2Fblog%2Fthe-highest-quality-codebase%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b0303d3e5-f633ea4b-5ad9-4108-a61f-87f3396e029d-000000/yQuA6fEK7-EmJJhuXhtH6V-PxTYM-DtFU-18gkuURhw=434
summary: The highest quality codebase (9 minute read) This developer ran an experiment where they looped an agent over a codebase for 36 hours to see what it did. The resulting app still worked, but with a few new bugs.

title: A brief history of specifiers and protocols
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-09, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fmacwright.com%2F2025%2F12%2F08%2Fmodule-specifiers-and-protocols.html%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019b0303d3e5-f633ea4b-5ad9-4108-a61f-87f3396e029d-000000/B0quh3o8obZPmq0yQgp4IJOdoGBsHdoVl1dV2Mss7mk=434
summary: A brief history of specifiers and protocols (5 minute read) Node.js introduced the node: protocol in 2021. Deno intro dude https imports in 2018, and then the npm: protocol in 2022. Deno then introduced package.json support in 2023 and the jsr: protocol in 2024. Also in 2024, Deno started moving away from HTTP imports. The current landscape is a messy state of affairs.

title: How To Reduce Cognitive Load in UX
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-09, Reading time: 11 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fpulse%2Fhow-reduce-cognitive-load-ux-vitaly-friedman-v0wle%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdesign/1/0100019b033868b5-c75a9450-f6ab-4878-86e4-7cc3a92580a6-000000/EL4aaWVeAtOGf-Nto2IU5RV52jfN_P-Vx3ciljTdFY0=434
summary: How To Reduce Cognitive Load in UX (11 minute read) Reducing cognitive load in UX isn't about oversimplifying complex interfaces. Expert software must match real-world complexity to be effective. Designers should break tasks into smaller steps, avoid forcing users to remember information across screens, and support decision-making through chunking options and clear labeling. The key is understanding how users actually work with a product rather than judging interfaces by appearance alone.

summary: Solana and Base â€œTwin Contractâ€ Bridge (3 minute read) The new Solana, Base bridge actually works. Any SPL token can get its own deterministic ERC-20 on Base via a factory contract, and Base tokens can likewise be deployed on Solana.

It is really easy to add bloat to a code base, but really hard to differentiate dead code from LLM slop leftovers.

title: The Bubble Is Labor
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-10, Reading time: 4 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fdanielmiessler.com%2Fblog%2Fthe-real-bubble-is-human-labor%3Futm_source=tldrnewsletter/1/0100019b0800a495-6cf89a61-eea1-4ee7-b503-834e8cf6e0fa-000000/nZ_xcKARZ8VglrpHS8cyt_LcX-8A-eSWnTcwAnIFg6g=435
summary: The Bubble Is Labor (4 minute read) Companies only hire people because they can't do all of the work themselves. If every founder could handle all of the tasks themselves, there wouldn't be anywhere near the number of jobs we have today. The only reason the current labor market exists is because there's a group of founders/owners who need help producing their goods and services. These people aren't required to hire anyone, and the moment they can do the work themselves, they will.
